review_title: This trust speak about inclusion but just look at the photos when one enters and see if it really reflects inclusion.

cons:
Little room for upward mobility unless you are white.
Blacks are not recognised for their hard work and more importantly not supported at this trust.

review_title: Who you know not what you know
pros: Job stability and friendly colleagues
cons:
A lot of staff are related, whole families work there - bias and favoritism is flourishing
No room for change or progress, management does not like change

Hard work is rewarded by more work and no recognition
Career progression is non-existent unless you're friends with managers

review_title: Bullying and harassment rife culture by senior management

review_title: The worst NHS trust I have ever worked for
pros: Some nice staff who were a pleasure to know and to work with
cons:
Non existent support from HR and OH. Accepted culture of bullying going unchecked (of which Ms Watts seems blissfully ignorant). 

Cliquey environment. From my experience, a lot of the staff who were working or getting jobs at C&W knew or were related to someone who already worked there, giving them an unfair advantage.  

Favouritism - certain staff (managers/supervisors and other staff) getting away with talking down to and generally treating other staff members badly, some staff getting away with doing the bare minimum and some who give 100% getting little or no recognition for their efforts.

Little or no chance of career progression unless your manager/supervisor likes you enough to help you move up the ladder.  

Left because my manager/supervisor was making my working life a living hell and no one cared enough to address it.

job_title: Postgraduate Centre Deputy Manager in London, England
pros: Continuing education provided and encouraged, great location, good work life balance. Good relationships between different departments. Good relationships between medical staff and clinical support staff.
cons: Area is not affordable on salary for a family home therefore commutes are a necessity.  While single this job was amazing. Staff accommodation is ideally located on site and wonderful location however this is for people who are single status.  Once married and children come along we had to move (like the majority) 1.5-2 hour commute by tube and walking, which is tough in the winter months and hard on work life balance. But that's the price many pay to have a great job in London.

pros: A good work ethic amongst peers, including good patient care.
cons:
Long hours, staying behind late.  A lack of promotion and training for BME staff.  This scenario applies to most of the NHS.  For example, newly qualified English nurses being given Band 6 jobs with little knowledge.

Also care should come before profits, and feel that this hospital is smartly private.

job_title: Accounts Payable Clerk in Isleworth, England
pros: They encourage development opportunities towards your employability skills through funded learning and development programmes which allow an individual member of staff to pursue career progression.
cons: The communication and accessibility between internal members of staff could improve due to the fact this is currently a difficulty in instances whereby an internal member of staff requires to be contacted regarding a query relating to their department.
